div.p:
I Having had cau≈øe my ≈øelfe to ≈øu≈øpect mine own condition, have been put to ≈øearch & try my ≈øelf, and not willing to bee mi≈øtaken in a point of ≈øo high concernment, I did lay and bind up together the≈øe Meditations (tending to the anatomizing, and the turning of the in≈øide outward of a Chri≈øtian) to be as a Looking-gla≈øs or Touch≈øtone for my help herein. And finding them ≈øomewhat u≈øefull for mine own purpo≈øe, and ≈øuppo≈øing they may be ≈øo al≈øo to ≈øome others in my ca≈øe; And having vehement cau≈øe to ≈øu≈øpect, that many thou≈øands among≈øt us in this golden time, go with the wind and tyde in the general profe≈ø≈øion of the Go≈øpel, and know not (becau≈øe they try not) what they are, or whither they are going, or what they doe: Therefore I have ≈øent it amongst you as a watch-word. And now con≈øider, were there any one among≈øt you to have a goodly Mannor in a remote country for which
he hath a conveyance for the payment down of a little ≈øum of money, and is to go ≈øhortly thither to ≈øhew his conveyance, pay his mony, and take his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: And ≈øhould I tell him his couveyance hath a flaw in it, and this is to be helpen before he go, and that the mony he iutends to carry will not pa≈øs for currant there; will he not be willing to hear and receive advice from me? To this purpo≈øe is all this that I am ≈øaying; That your Evidence as it now stands is not good for Heaven, the money you intend to carry with you, that you have to lay down for Chri≈øt, will not be taken for currant there. If I ≈øhould tell any of you that are trading with your whole ≈øtock, whether you ≈øhall thrive or not, or that you are in the way to be undone, and how you may thrive and be exceeding rich: Or if I ≈øhould tell you that are now going a voyage by Sea in a Ship, wherein you adventure your lives and all your e≈øtate in a dangerous pa≈ø≈øage between Rocks and Sands: Or you that are going about a work of mighty concernment, in a journey by land, in a ≈øolitary way, where are Robbers, Lyons, Bears, Wolves, Brakes, Pits, &c. and there is but
one way of ≈øafety onely, and that you are in the dangerous way, and ≈øhould offer to put you in the ≈øafe way: Or if I ≈øhould tell any of you that ≈øtand to be cho≈øen to a place of Preferment, that the having of it will make him, and the lo≈øing of it will undoe him, that he is out of the way for it, and which way hee may be ≈øure of it, who would not hearken to me? How acceptable would my conu≈øel be to ≈øuch? My de≈øign therfore in this word of Advice is, to ≈øhew you how among≈øt all your gettings you may get wi≈ødom Prov. 4. 7., and in your trading purcha≈øe that incomparable Pearl, which to get with the lo≈øs of all is an incomparble purcha≈øe Mat. 13. 45, 46, 47.; and to put you into the narrow way to eternal life, which ≈øo few find, and ≈øo many are mi≈øtaken in, who then would not but hearken to it? who would but be at the co≈øt and pains to buy and read it? And now if any one by the reading hereof ≈øhall find him≈øelf to be mi≈øtaken and out of the right way, it will be his advantage to be guided into it: It is better to run again than to run ami≈øs, Melius e≈øt recurrere quam male currere. and to beginne all again than to
end that which being ended will be to no purpo≈øe. And for others that are in the right way, albeit they may be hereby ≈øomwhat affrighted and ≈øhaken, yet it Bonum e≈øt timere. will make to their fa≈øter ≈øettlement at la≈øt. The la≈øt chapter of the Book * Hag. 2. 7. 9 Eph. 5. 6. Prov. 28. 14 is a peece of another mans, an Addition to the fourth chapter of the Book; for the further clearing of this point; That true Grace doth not lye in the degree or quantity, but in the nature and quality. And it is like to the man, learned indeed. All the defects and mistakes of my part of the work, mu≈øt be imputed to me & the Printer. All the good of it (if any bee therein) mu≈øt be attributed much of it to other men, ≈øome living, ≈øome dead, from whom I borrowed it. But (be it who≈øe it will) if you get any good by it; give to God the glory, for to him it doth belong; And look on me as a poor well wi≈øher to all that enquire what they may doe to be ≈øaved.

div.head: CHAP. 1.

argument.p: What Sincerity is, and what Hypocri≈øy is. The Nature of them.

div.p:
OUr work being to ≈øhew to man his uprightne≈øse towards God. Job. 33. 23. And therein to ≈øhew the right way to Salvation, and to unmark the Hypocrite, we ≈øhall for the doing hereof ob≈øerve this method. We ≈øhall fir≈øt of all for a ground-work or Foundation, lay downe what ≈øincerity, and what hypocri≈øy in men profe≈ø≈øing Religion are, the nature of them, and who is the ≈øincere Man, and who is the Hypocrite, and the ≈øeverall kinds of Hypocri≈øy and Hypocrites; and wherein Sincerity and Hypocri≈øy con≈øi≈øt; and this in a way of Explication. And then in the ≈øecond place, we ≈øhall make ≈øome kind of inferences thereupon. In which we ≈øhall ≈øet forth the≈øe things: 1. How far the Hypocrite may goe in the way with the true Chri≈øtian towards Heaven. 2. What is lacking in the Hypocrite, wherein he and the true Chri≈øtian differ,
the Hypocrite doth come ≈øhort, & the true Chri≈øtian doth goe beyond him. 3. The ≈øignes or degrees of Sincerity. 4. Motives or Encouragements to it. 5. The ≈øignes or degrees of Hypocri≈øie. 6. Arguments to per≈øwade again≈øt it. 7. And in the la≈øt place we ≈øhall adde ≈øome other things. And all this in a way of Application.
We ≈øhall begin with the fir≈øt, and open the nature of Sincerity and Hypocri≈øy together.

div.head: Sincerity what. Sincere man who.
div.p: Sincerity is that holy Frame of ≈øoule, wrought in it by Gods ≈øpirit, whereby the ≈øoule ≈øtands right to God in its purpo≈øe and endeavour to under≈øtand his mind from his word, that thereby it may exactly plea≈øe him in all things which he requireth therein. And ≈øuch a heart wherein this Sincerity is, is called a right heart, Acts 8. 21. P≈øal. 51. 10. a whole heart, P≈øal. 9. 1. 119. 2. a perfect heart, 1 Kings 11. 4. 15. 14. &c. A pure heart, P≈øal. 24. 4. Mat. 5. 8. and a ≈øingle heart, Ephe≈ø. 6. 5. And he that hath ≈øuch a heart, we call the true or Sincere Chri≈øtian, or the Chri≈øtian indeed, Ioh. 1. 47.

div.head: The Nature of Sincerity.
div.p:
To open this a little. This Sincerity lieth within: it is a heart work, or bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in the Soule, wherein the ≈øpirit of God doth dwell.
And therefore it is ≈øet forth in Scripture by the Metaphor of the Root of a Tree, Mat. 13. 21. or Foundation of a building, Mat. 7. 24. It is a frame of the heart, it ≈øpreads it ≈øelfe through the whole heart or Soule, under≈øtanding, con≈øcience, will, and affections. And there is an habitualne≈ø≈øe, and con≈øtant tenor and temper in it. And it is ≈øuch a thing, as like a ≈øpring that runs, it ≈øtreams & makes them reli≈øh of it: doth run into all the motions and operations of the Soule and body, called by one the proper quality of our obedience (if it may be ≈øaid to be a grace of it ≈øelfe, and not a thing that doth mingle it ≈øelfe with all graces, and (as one calls it) the Spirituall tune of all the graces in the Soule) it is then certainly a grace made up of many ≈øpirituall and choyce graces, like as was the holy oyle powred on the head and garments of the High-Prie≈øts, compounded and made up of many precious Ingredients. For it mu≈øt ≈øpring from the new life of the new Creature (the Soule whereof is Chri≈øt) which hath within it, and mu≈øt include Faith, love, and the re≈øt of the Graces that accompany ≈øalvation. For it mu≈øt flow from the pure and even workings of the internall Principles towards their ends. And therefore if a man act never ≈øo much in duties, and have not a divine Spirituall Spring, a heart impul≈øed, and moved
by Gods ≈øpirit acting in it: If there be not an acting of all the graces together in a harmony purely and really towards God, this Sincerity is not there. 1 Cor. 13. 1, 2. &c.

We call it the work of the Spirit, and, ≈øo it mu≈øt needs be, for as the naturall life of the body ≈øprings from the Soule within; ≈øo all the life of grace in the Soule, ≈øprings from the ≈øpirit of Chri≈øt within the Soule. Ioh. 6. 63.

We ≈øay the work begins with a mind ≈øavingly enlightned by the Word and Spirit of God. Iames 3. 17. Prov. 17. 2. Ephe≈ø. 1. 18, 19. P≈øal. 36. 10. Mat. 11. 25. For without knowledge the heart cannot be good, and without this there can be no Faith, no foundation of any Sincerity, nor any thing wherein, or whereby it may ≈øhew it ≈øelfe. And therefore when the Apo≈øtle Phil. 1. 9. 10. prayeth for the Philippians, that they might be ≈øincere, he begins with this, And thus I pray that your love may abound yet more and more in knowledge and in all judgement, that ye may approve things that are excellent, that ye may be ≈øincere &c. So that the Sincere Chri≈øtian is not only true, cordiall and reall in what he thinketh, ≈øaith and doth, but that which he thinketh, ≈øaith and doth, is generally according to the truth of the Go≈øpell, Gal. 6. 16. And, as many as walk according to this rule, &c. 3 Ioh. 4. 2 Ioh. 3. 4. I rejoyced greatly that I found of thy Children walking in truth,
as we have received a commandement, &c. Coll. 1. 13 2, 3, 4. 5. For otherwi≈øe, let what will be done, and let a man act in what he doth never ≈øo much ex animo from his very heart, and ≈øincerely according to the light he hath received (as many doe upon fal≈øe Principles) yet may he be called an Hypocrite.

div.head: Who were ≈øuch.
div.p: By the Sincere Chri≈øtian therefore throughout this Work, we under≈øtand ≈øuch a one as the Scripture noteth Nathaniel to be, Io. 1. 47. Behold a true I≈øraelite indeed in whom is no guile. And ≈øuch were David, 1 Kings 11. 4. P≈ø: 78. 72 Io≈øiah, 2 Kings 23 25. Hezekia, 2 Chron. 29 2. Abraham, Gen. 17. 1. and 24. 40. 2 Kings 22. 2. A≈øa, 2 Chron. 20. 32. 1 Kings ‚Ä¢ 1 14. Heb: 11. 4. and others, who≈øe Sincerity is thus de≈øcribed: of ≈øome of them, That their hearts were perfect with the Lord: of others that they did that which was right in the ≈øight of the Lord: of others, That they walked with God: of others that they walked before God: of others, that they did turne to the Lord with all their heart, with all their Soule, and with all their might: of others. That they laboured to keep their Con≈øciences voyd of offence. &c.

And the≈øe kind of men in Scripture language, are ≈øome-times called Holy men, or Saints, P≈øal, 37. 14, 28. Sometimes wi≈øe men, Mat. 25. 1. 2. Mat. 7. Sometimes perfect men, Gen. 6 9. Sometimes innocent men, Mat. 10. 16. Sometimes the true wor≈øhippers that wor≈øhip God in Spirit and Truth, Io. 4. 23. Sometimes ≈øuch as love the Lord Je≈øus in Sincerity, Ephe≈ø. 6. 24. Sometimes the pure in heart, Math. 5. 8. P≈øal. 24. 4. Sometimes the undefiled, P≈øal: 119. 1, 3. Sometimes the poore and needy, Mat. 5. 3. 7. P≈øal. 37. 14. Sometimes good men, P≈øal. 37. 14, 23. For the Sincere Chri≈øtian is a compleat Chri≈øtian, Coll: 2. 10. 4. 12. A perfect and entire Chri≈øtian, James 1. 4. Heb. 13. 21. And he that wants one grace, or one grace in truth, wants all grace. That known po≈øition in Ethiques, Quod virtutes ≈øunt connexae, is as true in Divinity as Morality; ≈øo that he that hath not all, hath indeed none at all; and hence it is, that true ble≈ø≈øedne≈ø≈øe is annexed to one of them. Mat. 5. 3. Ble≈ø-≈øed are the poor in ≈øpirit, &c. And the ≈øincere Chri≈øtian is more or le≈ø≈øe all this, Holy, Wi≈øe, Ju≈øt, Righteous, &c. So that by this work, we ≈øhall
≈øee (as in a gla≈ø≈øe) as well who is the Holy, Ju≈øt, and Righteous man, as who is the Sincere man.

This Sincerity now, and the Sincere man, are oppo≈øed to Hypocri≈øie and the Hypocrite. And that they may more lively appeare in their colours, we ≈øhall ≈øet them the one be≈øide the other, and in the next place, give a de≈øcription of Hypocri≈øy and the Hypocrite.

div.head: Hypocri≈øie, What. Hypocrite, Who.
div.p: Hypocri≈øie is an evill frame of Spirit, whereby a man would ≈øeem to be right towards God, and to be carried to act really for him, but in truth it is not ≈øo. Or where a man pretends to more good towards God or Men, without, then is within him, or whereby he would ≈øeem to him≈øelfe or others to be better then he is. He that hath this heart, is ≈øaid to have a heart and a heart, or a double heart, P≈øal. 12. 2. Iames 1. 8. A crooked heart, or perver≈øe heart, Prov. 12 8. and a divided heart, Ho≈øea 10. 2. 7. 14. And he that hath ≈øuch a heart, is he we intend by, and call the Hypocrite.

div.head: The Nature of Hypocri≈øie:
div.p:
But to open this Hypocri≈øie, and the nature of it, and to ≈øhew who we mean by this Hypocrite; we are to know fir≈øt of all: that Hypocri≈øy ≈øtands in oppo≈øition to the Truth and reality of a thing, and it ≈øtands al≈øo in oppo≈øition to
the Sincerity of a mans intention in the thing, and ≈øo Hypocri≈øy may be with reference to either of the≈øe. 2. By the Hypocrite in generall we doe not intend one that appears wor≈øe then he is indeed, as Peter did when he denied his Lord' (which yet he did not without Hypocri≈øy, being ≈øo well acquainted with him) Nor by the Hypocrite doe we intend, one that acts this part for once, or is deceitfull in one thing as Peter, and ≈øome others with him were, Gal. 2. 3, 14. For as a man may be in ≈øome Acts without Hypocri≈øie, and yet be an Hypocrite: ≈øo a man may be Hypocriticall in ≈øome Acts, and yet be ≈øincere; and there is ≈øome Hypocri≈øie in the be≈øt, who at one time or other, or in ≈øome things, may appeare better then they are.

div.head: The parts of Hypocri≈øy. Or wherein it ≈øheweth it ≈øelfe.
div.p: So the Hypocrites work lyeth in two things. 1. In the Simulation of good, that he may counterfeit and feigne that which indeed is not, that he may make ≈øhew of that good which he hath not at all, or el≈øe not in that mea≈øure he maketh ≈øhew of, being e≈øpecially ≈øwayed with the ≈øini≈øter re≈øpects of gaine and glory: And ≈øo his main ≈øtudy is, that he may ≈øeem better then he is, and that he may ≈øeem to doe better then he doth.

2. In Di≈ø≈øimulation, which is either of evill or of good, in di≈ø≈øembling and concealing that which indeed is evill; ≈øo his maine care is, that he may not appeare to be ≈øo bad as he is, and to doe ≈øo bad as he doth. And this di≈ø≈øembling and concealing of evill, is threefold. 1. Of evill

The di≈ø≈øembling of good is when we conceale and ≈ømother the good that is in us, for ≈øome advantage to our ≈øelves. So the Corinthians 1 Cor. 10. 19. went to the Jews fea≈øts for the company of their friends. And ≈øo Peter did Judaize, Gal. 2. 12. out of feare to offend, & de≈øire to plea≈øe other men. So that we ≈øay, that he is an Hypocrite not only that makes a ≈øeeming outward ≈øhew of what he hath not, but al≈øo that hath a true ≈øhew of what indeed there is not. The ≈øin of the Hypocrite is therefore not a ≈øin of infirmity but a ≈øinne of malignity, perver≈øene≈ø≈øe & contempt.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Of the ≈øeverall kinds of Hypocri≈øy and Sincerity. And of the Severall ≈øorts of Hypocrites.

div.p:
HYpocri≈øie, and ≈øo Sincerity al≈øo (as to the kinds thereof) are con≈øiderable in men diver≈øe wayes. 1. Mat. 3. 8. Acts 5. 41. 3. We grant 1. that the true Chri≈øtian ought ≈øo to love God and Chri≈øt at all times. 2. That it is in the nature of true Grace ≈øo to doe. 3. Io: 2. 23. E≈øay 58. 2. div.head: SECT. II.

argument.p: How farre the Hypocrite may goe in his out≈øide, with the true Chri≈øtian.

div.p:

He may be a bold Profe≈ø≈øor of the Faith, Acts 16. 17. Mat. 25. 1, 2, 3, 4. &c. He may a≈ø≈øociate him≈øelfe with Saints, Mat: 25. 1, 2, 3. He may di≈øpen≈øe the Sacraments, divinely and purely. But ≈øee more for the proofe of all the≈øe things Mat. 10. 7. 1 Cor. 5. 1, 2, &c. Rom. 2. 20. 1 Tim. 4. 16. &c. Luke 22. 14, 15, 16, &c. 2 Tim. 4. 10. I≈øa. 1. 11, 15. Mark 3. 12, 19. He may in all this ≈øervice of God be very diligent and indu≈øtrious, E≈øay 58. 2. Yet they ≈øeek me daily, and delight to know my ways, as a Nation that did Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and for≈øook not the Ordinances of their God, they aske of me the Ordinances of Ju≈øtice, they take delight in approaching to God. He may in ca≈øe of ≈øome trouble, or upon ≈øome other ≈øpeciall occa≈øion, make a ≈øolemne engagement
to God and man, of amendment of life, and in e≈øpeciall to forbear ≈øuch and ≈øuch things, or doe ≈øuch and ≈øuch duties, P≈øal: 78. 34, 35, 36. He may have or ≈øeem to have, and take ≈øome delight in all the≈øe things, I≈øa. 58. 2, 3. He may doe as much in the outworke, or upon the outward man, in mortification and ≈øelfe-deniall, by fa≈øting and the like; and goe as farre in appearance of like zeale, and devotion without by Teares &c. as any true Chri≈øtian ≈øhall doe, Mat. 6. 16. ≈øo Jehu and Paul when a Phari≈øee, Phill. 3. 6. Acts 22. 3. He may be≈øtow much to good u≈øes, and doe many ≈øingular good works, He may build Churches, give maintenance to Mini≈øters for Preaching, give to the poore, and the like,: Yea he may give all that he hath to ≈øuch u≈øes, 1 Cor. 13. 3. Ob. Again≈øt this it is objected out of Mat. 13. 21. that in time of per≈øecution they fall away.

An≈ø. This is meant of the one ≈øort of hearers that are repre≈øented by the ≈øtony ground, not them that are noted by the thorny ground, which went farther and endured the ≈øcorching of the Sun, and fell away after. 5. And when there were extraordinary gifts in the Church, as when there was the gift of Miracles, extraordinary Prophe≈øy or the like, the Hypocrite had as large a ≈øhare therein, as the true Chri≈øtian had, Mat. 7. 22. 1 Cor: 13. 2. And how many that are called Chri≈øtians, come ≈øhort of this?

div.head: SECT. III.

argument.p: How farre the Hypocrite may goe in his In≈øide with the true Chri≈øtian.

div.p:
But the Hypocrite, who≈øe heart is yet unchanged, may goe farther, and neerer to the Kingdome of God (which is within) Ro: 14.
17. then all this, and yet come ≈øhort of it. For he may be another man as Saul was 1 Sam. 10. 9. he may be ≈øeemingly regenerate, come very neere to, or have the ≈øemblance of all the ≈øaving graces, and workes of the true Chri≈øtian in the ≈øoule. And therefore there are found in ≈øome of their hearts, all the≈øe following things.

div.head: In his Illumination.
div.p: 1. Illumination. He may not only heare, but receive, and entertaine the word, Luke 8. 12, 13, 14. And have as much of the ≈øpeculative knowledge of God and Chri≈øt, the word of God and Go≈øpell, as is in any true Chri≈øtian, 1 Cor. 13. 2. And though I under≈øtand all mysteries, and all knowledge &c. and have not love, I am nothing, Heb. 6. 4. It is impo≈ø≈øible for tho≈øe who were once enlightned, &c. Rom: 2. 18, 20. Io. 3. 10. 2 Pe. 2. 20. Numb. 24. 3, 4.

div.head: In his Memory.
div.p: 2. He may have as good a memory to retain the things that he doth know of God and Chri≈øt, as the true Chri≈øtian hath. He may by the frequent exerci≈øe of it about Heavenly things improve it ≈øo, as to be able to repeat a Sermon by it, which ≈øeems to be implied, 1 Cor. 13. 2.

div.head: In his Soundne≈øse of Opinion.
div.p: 3. He may be as Orthodox and ≈øound in his Judgement about the things of God, as the be≈øt Chri≈øtian, Rom: 2. 20. Rev. 2. 13.

div.head: In his zeale again≈øt the Heterodox.
div.p: 4. He may in (appearance) be as zealous again≈øt them that are un≈øound and Heterodox in judgement as the be≈øt Chri≈øtian may be, Rev. 2. 3, 4. Phill. 3. 4, 5.

div.head: In his Selfe conviction.
div.p:
5. He may have a large conviction upon his Spirit, as to his Judgement and Rea≈øon, he may be, as Judgement, Rea≈øon, and Per≈øwa≈øion. much for good, and all that is good, as the true Chri≈øtian, and he may goe very farre in his per≈øwa≈øion. He may be convinced in his judgement and per≈øwa≈øion of all the≈øe things. 1. The ≈øinfulne≈ø≈øe of his own ways, Rom. 2. 15. Which ≈øhew the work of the Law written in their hearts, their con≈øcience al≈øo bearing witne≈ø≈øe, and their thoughts the mean while accu≈øing or el≈øe excu≈øing one another, Judas, Mat. 27. 3. 2. Of the dangerous con≈øequen≈øes of his ≈øinne, Rom: 2. 15. 1. 32. Who knowing the judgement of God that they which commit ≈øuch things are worthy of Death. &c. 3. That there is a nece≈ø≈øity of a change. 4. Of the Equity and rea≈øonablene≈ø≈øe of Gods ways and commands. 5. Of the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe and goodne≈ø≈øe of Gods ways. 6. Of the truth of his promi≈øes and threatnings. 7. He may have ≈øtrong inclinations to clo≈øe with Chri≈øt, but upon his own and not upon Chri≈øts termes. 8. He may be per≈øwaded and
re≈øolved to clo≈øe fully with Chri≈øt, and to comply wholly with his will hereafter, but not yet; Or to doe it pre≈øently, but not in all times, places and things; or to doe all his will in the out≈øide and forme, but not in reality and Truth. See for proof of all this, Luke 8. 13, 14. Heb. 6. 5. Mark 6. 20. Mat. 3. 6. Rev. 3. 15. Ho≈øea 7. 8. Luke 9. 59. 61. 57. Ezech. 33. 31. 32. compared with Ezech. 8. 7, 8, 9.

div.head: In his Repentance.
div.p: 6. He may hereupon have ≈øome ≈øhakings and tremblings of heart, or a heart wounded for ≈øin be under the feare of eternall vengeance, and have a kind of Repentance for his ≈øinne, as Judas Mat. 27. 3. I have ≈øinned &c. P≈øal. 78. 34, 35, 36. Saul 1 Sam. 15. 24, 30, I have ≈øinned &c.

div.head: In his feare of God.
div.p: 7. He may feare the Lord and his judgements. James 2. 19. The Divells believe and tremble. E≈øay 33. 13, 14. 15. The ≈øinners in Zion are afraid, fearfulne≈ø≈øe hath ≈øurprized the Hypocrites, Who among us ≈øhall dwell with devouring fire? &c Exod. 14. 31.

div.head: In his delight in the word of God.
div.p:
8. He may have ≈øome delight in the word of God, he readeth and heareth, and he may de≈øire and delight in the be≈øt Preachers and Preaching, Heb. 6. 5. It is impo≈ø≈øible for ≈øuch as are enlightned, have ta≈øted, (that is to ≈øay) the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of the good word of God, If they fall away &c. Luke
8. 13. They on the Rock are they who when they hear, receive the word with joy. Ioh. 5. 35. Chri≈øt ≈øpeaks to the Jewes of John the Baptist, and his Mini≈øtry, He was a burning and a ≈øhining light, And you were willing for a ≈øea≈øon to rejoyce in that light. And it is ≈øaid of Herod, that he feared John and heard him gladly. Marke 6. 20. Ezek. 33. 32. And Loe, thou art unto them a very lively ≈øong of one that hath a plea≈øant voyce, or can play with an in≈øtrument, for they heare thy words and doe them not, E≈øay 58. 23.
9. He may perhaps be devout indeed, and take much delight in the ≈øervice of God, E≈øay 58. 2 Or he may at lea≈øt ≈øeem to doe ≈øo, E≈øay 58. 2 Jer. 7. 9.

div.head: In his Faith.
div.p: 10. He may have an Hi≈øtoricall Faith, give a≈ø≈øent to, and believe the truth of the whole word of God, James 2, 19. The Divells believe and tremble.

11. He may not only heare, but entertaine and feel ‚Ä¢ the word quick and powerfull, and have ≈øome fal≈øe per≈øwa≈øion or fancy, that the promi≈øe of the Go≈øpell doth belong to him, and that Chri≈øt and Salvation by him is his, Luke 8. 13. They on the Rock are they which when they heare, receive the word with joy, and have no root, which for a while believe, and in time of Temptation fall away. Io 2. 23, 24. Many believe in his name, &c. But Ie≈øus did not commit him≈øelfe to them, for he knew what
was in man, &c. Ezek. 33. 31, 32. Acts 8. 13. Simon him≈øelfe believed al≈øo, v. 19. 20, 21. &c. Io: 4. 41, 42, 45, 46, 48. &c.

div.head: In his Peace of Con≈øcience, joy, &c.
div.p:
12. He may, from the di≈øcovery made to his ≈øoule, of the ble≈ø≈øed e≈øtate of the Believers, and the fal≈øe per≈øwa≈øion of his heart, bred and fed by Satan and his own flattery of him≈øelfe, that he is one of them, and ≈øhall have his part in heaven with them, have ≈øome ≈ølight impre≈ø≈øions of joy within him, and ≈øome kind of peace of Con≈øcience, He may have a kind of hope and patience, to wait and look for the thing he doth believe he ≈øhall have: And by all this, think that his e≈øtate is very good, and better then other mens. And for the proof of all the≈øe things ≈øee Mat. 13 20, 21. But he that received the ≈øeed into stony places, the ≈øame is he that beareth the word, and anon with joy receiveth it, yet hath he not root in him≈øelfe, Io. 5. 35. They did for a ≈øea≈øon rejoyce in the light, &c. Heb. 6. 4, 5. For it is impo≈ø≈øible for tho≈øe who were once enlightned, (that is) that are in≈øtructed by the Go≈øpell of Chri≈øt, in the way of ≈øalvation by Chri≈øt, Ephe≈ø: 1. 18. (And have ta≈øted) that is, have had a little reli≈øh of the word, who≈øe heart and affection is for a time taken with the newne≈ø≈øe and plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe of the Chri≈øtian doctrine, and hath ≈øome tran≈øient motion by it, or generall di≈øpo≈øition towards
Chri≈øt in it, a Ta≈øt like that the Cook hath by dipping his finger in the di≈øh, and the licking of it, that is not fed or ≈øtrengthned by it, or like as the child that catcheth at the brea≈øt, and doth not ≈øuck, is never the better for it. [The heavenly gift] That is, either Chri≈øt the gift of God, Io. 4. 10. Or the heavenly calling, Heb: 3. 1. or a Temporary Faith (which ≈øeems to be all one) for Chri≈øt by Faith received, is the only food of the Soule Jo. 4. 14. and 6. 33, 35. And by this doth the ≈øoule live, as the body doth by the receiving in of its naturall food. [And were made partakers of the Holy Ghost] that is, Either of the common work and operation thereof in generall, or ≈øuch extraordinary gifts thereof, which the Church had for that time, for the pre≈øent nece≈ø≈øity thereof, as Miracles, Prophe≈øy, and happily ≈øome inward Revelations and In≈øpirations that do not continue to this day in ordinary with the Church. [And have ta≈øted the good word of God] (that is) ha ‚Ä¢ h ≈øome pa≈ø≈øionate apprehen≈øions of the nece≈ø≈øity, goodne≈ø≈øe, ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe and profit of Chri≈øt, the ≈øubject of it, and the Go≈øpell and promi≈øes of Chri≈øt, &c. and ≈øome groundle≈ø≈øe per≈øwa≈øion that it belongs to him, he hath a little reli≈øh hereof, as a child that will not, or cannot take the brea≈øt, and doth but ≈ønatch at it, hath only a ta≈øt of it, and is not fed, and nouri≈øhed by it, as the child is that
doth hold, and ≈øuck its belly full. As the true believer; who doth ≈øo de≈øire and receive the word, that he doth grow thereby, 2 Pe. 2. 2. [And the powers of the world to come.] (that is) which hath had a ta≈øt, (which mu≈øt be ≈øupplyed) of the powers of the world to come. By the≈øe words ≈øome under≈øtand, all the Spirituall ble≈ø≈øings, and Priviledges of the Go≈øpell Church, as a ta≈øt of Chri≈øt, the common gifts of the ≈øpirit; outward, Prophe≈øy, Prayer, and the like: Inward, as Faith, Hope, Joy, and the like. And others under≈øtand by it the joys of Heaven. And ≈øo that as the I≈øraelites did ta≈øt of the fruits of the Land of Canaan, and never came there to eat thereof; So ≈øome Hypocrites may have ≈øome litle ta≈øt of the ioves of Heaven, that ≈øhall never come there. And in both ≈øen≈øes, but e≈øpecially in this la≈øt ≈øen≈øe it ≈øeems to be thus farre intended, that upon his contemplation of Heaven, he may be in a rapture: the other things being included in the former words. See for this Mat. 13. 20, 21, 22. Numb: 23. 10. and 24. 2, 3, &c. and 13. 26. and 14. 27. &c.

div.head: In his love of God.
div.p: 13. He may perhaps hereupon, or for ≈øome other good felt, apprehended, or hoped for by him from God, have ≈øome ≈øeeming love to God and Chri≈øt, 2 Tim: 3. 4. Ephe≈ø. 6. 24.

div.head: In his Love of the Godly.
div.p: He may al≈øo have ≈øome ≈øeeming love to, and delight in the company of the Saints, and true Chri≈øtians; ≈øo the fooli≈øh Virgins ≈øeem to have a love to, and delight in the fellow≈øhip of the wi≈øe Virgins, Mat: 25. 1, 2, 3. &c.

div.head: In his Love of Ordinances.
div.p: 14. He may al≈øo have ≈øome ≈øeeming love to, and delight in the Ordinances of God, Ezek. 33. 31. E≈øay 58, 2. Yet they ≈øeek me daily and delight to know my wayes, &c. Mat. 13. 20, 21.

div.head: In his Love of Graces.
div.p: 15. He may have ≈øome ≈øeeming love to, and ≈øome de≈øire after the Gifts and Graces of Gods Spirit, Mat: 25. 1, 2, 6. &c. So the fooli≈øh Virgins ≈øeemed to de≈øire the oyle of the wi≈øe Virgins, Acts 8. 18, 19.
16. He may ≈øeem to lament after God, and after the vi≈øible ≈øignes and manife≈øtations of his pre≈øence departed from him, 1 Sam: 28. 15.

div.head: In his other ≈øeeming Graces.
div.p:
17. He may perhaps get ≈øome appearance of all the other gifts and graces of the Spirit, as Humility, Mercy, Meekne≈ø≈øe, Patience, and the like. For there is no kind of grace or duty required by God, but there is a like to it, nor work done by the true Chri≈øtian, but the Hypocrite can imitate. Therefore we find a like to true Faith, Repentance and Love. And
the Hypocrite may be per≈øwaded, that he hath indeed tho≈øe very graces, and doth indeed tho≈øe very works, as the fooli≈øh Virgins, Mat. 25. 1, 2, &c.

div.head: In a growth of Grace.
div.p: 16. He may in appearance thrive, and grow herein towards perfection: As the three ≈øorts of bad hearers did, Luke 8. 12, 13, 14. &c. and Mat. 13. 25.
17. And by all this he may get a great name and e≈øteeme among≈øt men, for a true Chri≈øtian, Mat. 25. 1, 2. &c.

18. And he may thus continue without any ≈øu≈øpicion to his dying day, Luke 25. 11. and 13. 25, 26, 27, 28. But for the farther clearing of all the≈øe la≈øt named particulars within this Section. See Numb: 23. 10. Let me dye the death of the Righteous. Numb. 24. 2, 3, &c. 1 Cor: 11. 30, 31, 32. For this cau≈øe many are weake &c. If we would judge our ≈øelves &c. but when we are judged, we are chastned of the Lord, that we be not condemned &c. which would ≈øeem to have this intimation, that notwith≈øtanding all your gifts, Parts, and progre≈ø≈øe in Chri≈øtianity, if you have ≈øecret evills, and do not labour to find them out, and judge your ≈øelves for them, you may be condemned with the world, 1 Cor: 15. 19. If in this life only we have hope in Chri≈øt &c. which words ≈øeem to imply thus much, That if all our Parts, gifts,
de≈øires, works, &c. reach and look no farther, and la≈øt no longer, then for this pre≈øent life, that our Faith, Hope, &c. be but temporary moved from, and carried to ≈øomething that is not beyond this life, we are in a ≈øad ca≈øe, it will doe us no more good then the wealth glory, and good things which Dives had, Luke 16. 25. Io. 6. 27. 1 Cor: 13. 8, 13. 1 Pet. 1. 22, 24, 25. Seeing ye have purified, &c. Being borne again not of Corruptible ≈øeed &c. By which words are intimated thus much, That, unle≈ø≈øe you manife≈øt the work of the ≈øpirit within you, in obedience to the truth, by having your hearts purifyed, and by an unfeyned, pure, and fervent love of the Saints, beyond that work which is wrought in the hearts of Hypocrites, you will not have the evidence within you of that Regeneration which is true, and effectually wrought of God by his ≈øpirit through the word, by which there is effected an immortall ≈øeed of Grace that abideth for ever. But if it be only ≈øome morall vertues, or common gifts, be they never ≈øo excellent and glorious, that have the face of the new Creature, and he in whom they are, be not a new Creature indeed, they are reckoned with God but as fle≈øh, which is as gr ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe, and the flower of the field, they will doe a man no more good, nor la≈øt any longer then riches, honours, and ≈øuch like things, which
are but for this life only, Phil. 3. 4, 5. 2 Pe. 3. 4 It is ≈øaid, P≈øal: 106. 11, 12. then believed they his words. (that is) when they had ≈øeen ≈øuch ≈øignall manife≈øtations of Gods power, and working for them again≈øt their enemies, they were for the pre≈øent as full of Faith in God, his promi≈øe and joy, as a bladder of wind, they ≈øoon forgat &c. it had no root nor well grounded principle, they fell back. But lu≈øted exceedingly &c. Mat. 13. 21, 22. Phill: 3. 4, 5, 19. 1 Tim: 6. 5. 2 Pe. 3, 4. Exod: 14. 31. compared with 15. 23, 24. Numb. 13. 26, 27. &c. 14. 1. 27. &c. And thus he may ≈øtrive in his inward, as well as in his outward man, to enter into heaven, and not be able, Luke 13. 24.

div.head: SECT. IV.

argument.p: What it is that doth carry the Hypocrite thus farre. And why he goeth no farther.

div.p:
If it be asked how it comes to pa≈ø≈øe, that an Hypocrite doth goe ≈øo farre. We an≈øwer. 1. That he may be drawn or driven to it by ≈øome or all of the≈øe following means. 1. He may be drawn hereunto by the work of his naturall Con≈øcience, Rom: 2. 15. Rom. 1. 32. For when the Gentiles that have not the law, doe by nature the things contained in the Law, the≈øe having not the Law, are a Law to them≈øelves, which ≈øhew the work of the Law written in their hearts, their Con≈øciences al≈øo
bearing witne≈ø≈øe &c. Prov. 20. 27. The ≈øpirit of a man is the Candle of the Lord, ≈øearching all the inward parts of the belly. Or by occa≈øion and rea≈øon of ≈øome eminent and miraculous work of God done before their eyes, Io. 4. 41, 44, 45, 46. &c. Except ye ≈øee ≈øignes and wonders ye will not believe; or by occa≈øion of ≈øome eminent work of Gods Providence done for his people, or again≈øt their enemies; or by the feare of death, or ≈øome great affliction upon him, P≈øal. 78. 34. When he flew them then they ≈øought him &c. P≈øal. 106. 11, 12. And the waters covered their enemies &c. then believed they his words, they ≈øang his prai≈øe, they ≈øoon forgat his works, &c. Or by occa≈øion of ≈øome light breaking in, and ≈øome powerfull conviction upon the Con≈øcience by the word and Spirit of God, whereby it is pre≈ø≈øed and moved to doe what it doth. Perhaps it cannot otherwi≈øe be in peace; It may be it is convinced, there are ≈øome good and de≈øireable things to be had, and duties to be done in the profe≈ø≈øion of the Chri≈øtian Faith, and happily it may find more temporall good in ≈øuch a life, then in a wicked loo≈øe life. 2. He may be moved or brought hereunto by Education, di≈øcipline, or example of Parents, or ≈øuch like per≈øons, under whom he hath been brought up.
